_header: I must go walk the wood so wild
Note:
The first line occurs as a title in London, British Library Sloane 3501, f. 2v; referred to by title/first line in a Lyffe of Sir Peter Carew, ed. Phillipps (1840)
XPhillipps, Sir Thomas. “The Life of Sir Peter Carew, of Mohun Ottery, co. Devon.” Archaeologia 28 (1840): 96-151, 113.
_description: The Banished Lover — fifteen 5-line stanzas including refrain, ‘And all for your loue my dere’

BLAdd22718.Transcription: I muste nedes wander here & there& yn dedly fare

TCD160.First Lines:
I muste go walke the woodes so wyldand wander here &
                    there…
TCD160.Last Lines:
…that ar the causers of this stryfe& all for your Loue my
                    dere
TCD160.Editions:
Muir,  Kenneth. 
             Unpublished Poems [by] Sir Thomas Wyatt and His Circle.
English Reprints Series
         18. Liverpool: Liverpool UP, 1961: 26-8.

HunEL34B60.First Lines:
I must go walke the wood so wylde& wander here &
                    therin dred & dedly fere…
HunEL34B60.Last Lines:
…but when that I of hur bewtye do thynkeand all for my loue my
                    dere
HunEL34B60.Note:
Second occurrence in this MS; written as prose into margins: lines 1-5
                    on 108v, 6-10 and 16-20 on f. 107v, 6-9 on f. 109, by a
                    hand of very end of the fifteenth century or sixteenth century; with variant
                    refrain, ‘and all for my loue my dere’ or ‘and all for your
                    loue my dere’.
